title: Maryam rejects e-bus fare hike as Punjab cabinet okays key reforms
excerpt: LAHORE: Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz Sharif chaired the 30th cabinet meeting on Wednesday, during which a proposal to increase fares of electric buses in Multan, Rawalpindi and Lahore was...
content:
Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz Sharif chaired the 30th meeting of the provincial cabinet on Wednesday. The meeting was held at the Civil Secretariat and focused on major administrative and development reforms across the province.

During the meeting, Maryam Nawaz rejected a proposal to increase fares for electric buses operating in Lahore, Multan, and Rawalpindi. She directed the authorities to keep the fares unchanged, saying that affordable transport is essential for the public.

The cabinet reviewed several important matters, including law and order, agriculture, and education. It officially endorsed the ban on the proscribed organisation Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan (TLP). The cabinet also approved the hiring of School Teacher Interns (STIs) in government schools to fill teaching gaps and ensure smooth academic operations.

A significant decision was the approval of the Punjab Protection of Ownership of Immovable Property Ordinance 2025. This initiative was launched under the vision, "One who possesses it, owns it." The ordinance aims to protect the ownership rights of citizens and prevent illegal occupation of properties.

The cabinet also gave the green light to the Chief Minister High-Tech Farm Mechanisation Finance Programme. Under this scheme, farmers will receive modern farming equipment such as super seeders and advanced machinery at a 60% government subsidy. Officials informed that more than 10,000 applications have been received so far, with over 1,500 submitted through the Bank of Punjab.

The meeting decided that the sugarcane crushing season across Punjab will begin on November 15. Officials shared progress on the Kisan Card Phase-II programme, stating that Rs100 billion have already been distributed among farmers, while Rs70 billion have been recovered from the previous phase. The repayment system has also improved, allowing second-phase disbursements within 24 hours after clearance.
author: The News International
